questions.text: A newborn is born with lower extremity paralysis, an absent sacrum, and impaired bladder and bowel control. On examination, there is a clear demarcation between the normal and affected spinal regions. What is the most likely diagnosis for this infant's condition, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Caudal regression syndrome; Abnormal development of the lower spinal cord and vertebral structures.

options.label: B
options.text: Spina bifida occulta; A neural tube defect resulting in a bony spinal defect

options.label: C
options.text: Neurofibromatosis type 1; A genetic disorder causing neurofibromas and spinal abnormalities.

questions.correct_answer: A. Caudal regression syndrome; Abnormal development of the lower spinal cord and vertebral structures.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Caudal regression syndrome; Abnormal development of the lower spinal cord and vertebral structures.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caudal regression syndrome is characterized by lower extremity paralysis, sacral agenesis, and bladder and bowel dysfunction, caused by abnormal development of the lower spine and spinal cord.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4211
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4211

questions.text: A preterm infant born at 28 weeks gestation has been receiving mechanical ventilation for several weeks due to respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Despite gradual improvement in lung function, the infant continues to require supplemental oxygen. What is the most appropriate term for this infant's condition, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN); Delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid causing respiratory distress.

options.label: B
options.text: Meconium aspiration syndrome; Airway obstruction due to meconium in the air passages.

options.label: C
options.text: Neonatal pneumonia; Infection of the lung tissue causing respiratory distress.

options.label: D
options.text: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD); Lung injury from prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen exposure.

questions.correct_answer: D. Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD); Lung injury from prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen exposure.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a chronic lung disease of preterm infants, caused by prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen exposure, leading to impaired alveolar development and fibrosis .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9174
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9174

questions.text: A term newborn with jaundice is prescribed phototherapy due to elevated bilirubin levels. The infant's mother asks if she should continue breastfeeding during phototherapy. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding breastfeeding during phototherapy?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue breastfeeding without interruption, as breast milk is beneficial for jaundiced infants.

options.label: B
options.text: Discontinue breastfeeding temporarily and switch to formula feeding until phototherapy is completed.

options.label: C
options.text: Offer breast milk between phototherapy sessions, but limit exposure to phototherapy lights.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid breastfeeding entirely until bilirubin levels normalize to prevent further jaundice.

questions.correct_answer: A. Continue breastfeeding without interruption, as breast milk is beneficial for jaundiced infants.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Continue breastfeeding without interruption, as breast milk is beneficial for jaundiced infants.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Continue breastfeeding during phototherapy for neonatal jaundice, as it supports hydration, promotes bilirubin excretion, and ensures proper nutrition for the infant.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3789
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3789

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with jaundice and pale stools. Physical examination reveals no hepatosplenomegaly, and the infant appears healthy. Laboratory tests show elevated direct bilirubin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis for this infant's condition, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Gilbert syndrome; Impaired bilirubin conjugation due to a genetic enzyme deficiency.

options.label: B
options.text: Hemolytic anemia; Increased bilirubin production from excessive red blood cell breakdown.

options.label: C
options.text: Dubin-Johnson syndrome; Impaired bilirubin excretion due to a genetic defect in hepatic transport.

options.label: D
options.text: Physiological jaundice of the newborn; A normal variant of neonatal jaundice.

questions.correct_answer: C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome; Impaired bilirubin excretion due to a genetic defect in hepatic transport.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dubin-Johnson syndrome; Impaired bilirubin excretion due to a genetic defect in hepatic transport.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dubin-Johnson syndrome causes chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to a genetic defect in bilirubin excretion, presenting with jaundice, elevated direct bilirubin levels, and pale stools in the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8315
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8315

questions.text: A term newborn is exclusively breastfed and develops jaundice on the second day of life. Physical examination reveals no hepatosplenomegaly or signs of illness, and the infant is latching well during feeds. Laboratory tests show elevated bilirubin levels. What is the most likely cause of this infant's jaundice, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN); Maternal-fetal blood group incompatibility leading to increased bilirubin production.

options.label: B
options.text: Physiological jaundice of the newborn; A normal variant of neonatal jaundice due to immature liver function.

options.label: C
options.text: Breastfeeding jaundice; Elevated bilirubin levels due to inadequate breast milk intake and dehydration.

options.label: D
options.text: Dubin-Johnson syndrome; A genetic disorder causing impaired bilirubin excretion.

questions.correct_answer: C. Breastfeeding jaundice; Elevated bilirubin levels due to inadequate breast milk intake and dehydration.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breastfeeding jaundice occurs in the first week of life due to insufficient milk intake, leading to dehydration and increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. Early breastfeeding support is crucial to resolve the condition .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4106
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4106

questions.text: A healthy term newborn is exclusively breastfed and develops jaundice on the 11th day of life, peaking in severity. Physical examination reveals no hepatosplenomegaly or other signs of illness. Laboratory tests show elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels. What is the most likely cause of this infant's jaundice, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN); Maternal-fetal blood group incompatibility leading to increased bilirubin production.

options.label: B
options.text: Physiological jaundice of the newborn; A normal variant of neonatal jaundice due to immature liver function.

options.label: C
options.text: Breast milk jaundice; Elevated bilirubin levels attributed to factors in breast milk that inhibit bilirubin conjugation.

options.label: D
options.text: Dubin-Johnson syndrome; A genetic disorder causing impaired bilirubin excretion.

questions.correct_answer: C. Breast milk jaundice; Elevated bilirubin levels attributed to factors in breast milk that inhibit bilirubin conjugation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Breast milk jaundice; Elevated bilirubin levels attributed to factors in breast milk that inhibit bilirubin conjugation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast milk jaundice typically peaks around the second week of life in healthy, exclusively breastfed infants due to substances in breast milk that inhibit bilirubin conjugation. It is a benign condition that resolves with continued breastfeeding.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4106
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4106

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 32 weeks gestation presents with signs of preterm labor. To assess fetal lung maturity, a fetal lung surfactant analysis is performed on amniotic fluid obtained via amniocentesis. The lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio is found to be 2:1. What does this result indicate regarding fetal lung maturity, and what is the significance of the L/S ratio in assessing lung development?

options.label: A
options.text: Fetal lung maturity is uncertain; additional tests are needed.

options.label: B
options.text: Fetal lung maturity is adequate, indicating a lower risk of respiratory distress syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: Fetal lung maturity is immature, indicating a higher risk of respiratory distress syndrome.

options.label: D
options.text: Fetal lung maturity is not related to the L/S ratio.

questions.correct_answer: B. Fetal lung maturity is adequate, indicating a lower risk of respiratory distress syndrome.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fetal lung maturity is adequate, indicating a lower risk of respiratory distress syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An L/S ratio of 2:1 or greater indicates mature fetal lungs with adequate surfactant production, reducing the risk of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4004
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4004

questions.text: A preterm newborn in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) exhibits apnea of prematurity and intermittent bradycardia. The medical team initiates caffeine citrate therapy. What is the primary mechanism of action of caffeine citrate in the management of apnea of prematurity in preterm infants?

options.label: A
options.text: Central nervous system depression to reduce respiratory drive.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an antagonist of adenosine to enhance respiratory center activity.

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of bronchoconstriction to improve airway patency.

options.label: D
options.text: Promotion of bowel motility to prevent gas trapping.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is an antagonist of adenosine to enhance respiratory center activity.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is an antagonist of adenosine to enhance respiratory center activity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caffeine citrate treats apnea of prematurity by antagonizing adenosine receptors, stimulating the central respiratory center, and enhancing respiratory drive in preterm infants .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3993
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3993

questions.text: A full-term newborn presents with abdominal distension, bloody stools, and signs of sepsis. Abdominal imaging reveals the presence of pneumatosis intestinalis. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with pneumatosis intestinalis in neonates, and what is the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC); Ischemic injury to the intestinal wall.

options.label: B
options.text: Hirschsprung disease; Congenital absence of ganglion cells in the colon.

options.label: C
options.text: Intestinal atresia; Obstruction of the bowel lumen.

options.label: D
options.text: Meconium ileus; Thickened meconium causing intestinal obstruction.

questions.correct_answer: A. Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC); Ischemic injury to the intestinal wall.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC); Ischemic injury to the intestinal wall.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is characterized by abdominal distension, bloody stools, and pneumatosis intestinalis on imaging, caused by ischemic injury to the immature intestinal wall in neonates.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4089
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4089

questions.text: A preterm infant born at 28 weeks gestation in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) experiences episodes of apnea, cyanosis, and bradycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention for managing apnea of prematurity in this newborn?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administering caffeine citrate.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caffeine citrate is the first-line treatment for apnea of prematurity, working as a respiratory stimulant by blocking adenosine receptors and enhancing the central respiratory drive.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3993
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3993

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated for multiple congenital anomalies. The child has vertebral defects, imperforate anus, and a tracheoesophageal fistula. Additionally, there is a single umbilical artery noted. Which of the following best describes this cluster of anomalies?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) VACTERL association

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ VACTERL association is a constellation of congenital anomalies involving the vertebrae, anorectal region, cardiovascular system, tracheoesophageal structures, renal system, and limbs, often associated with a single umbilical artery.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3828
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3828

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with chronic respiratory symptoms undergoes testing for a suspected genetic disorder. Nasal transmembrane potential difference (NPD) measurement is performed, and the results show increased sodium absorption. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis is characterized by increased sodium absorption and reduced chloride secretion due to CFTR dysfunction, findings confirmed by nasal potential difference (NPD) testing.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8205
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8205

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with a history of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and recurrent respiratory infections. Physical examination reveals azoospermia on semen analysis. Nasal cultures show chronic infections with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Young syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Young syndrome involves obstructive azoospermia, chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa colonization, caused by inspissated mucus in the respiratory and reproductive tracts.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9066
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9066

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, the tonsils are enlarged with exudates, and anterior cervical lymph nodes are tender. The child complains of a stomach ache and has a red, sandpaper-like rash on the trunk and extremities. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Group A Streptococcus (GAS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scarlet fever is caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS) and presents with pharyngitis, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and a sandpaper-like rash due to exotoxin production.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 5812
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 5812

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old child presents with a sudden onset of high fever, sore throat, and drooling. The child prefers to sit upright and leans forward to breathe. On examination, there is a muffled voice, and the uvula is not visible. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administer intravenous antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravenous antibiotics are the first-line treatment for acute epiglottitis, with close monitoring for airway obstruction and readiness for emergent intervention if needed.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8707
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8707

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with congenital heart defects, characteristic facial anomalies including hypertelorism and low-set ears, and recurrent viral and fungal infections. There is also evidence of hypocalcemia. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DiGeorge syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) is characterized by congenital heart defects, facial anomalies, immunodeficiency due to thymic hypoplasia, and hypocalcemia due to parathyroid dysfunction.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4242
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4242

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to a friendly and outgoing personality, along with distinct facial features such as a wide mouth, full lips, and a flattened nasal bridge. Physical examination reveals supravalvular aortic stenosis and peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis. The child also has developmental delays and a characteristic 'elfin' appearance. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Williams syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Williams syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by 'elfin' facial features, a friendly personality, developmental delays, and cardiovascular anomalies such as supravalvular aortic stenosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9412
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9412

questions.text: A newborn presents with cyanosis and respiratory distress shortly after birth. A physical examination reveals a single loud second heart sound and a continuous murmur along the left sternal border. An echocardiogram confirms a discordant ventriculo-arterial connection. What is the most likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation?
questions.correct_answer: C. Transposition of the great arteries
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transposition of the great arteries

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transposition of the great arteries is a cyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by a discordant ventriculo-arterial connection, requiring prompt diagnosis and intervention to enable adequate oxygenation.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9337
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9337

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is evaluated for suspected congenital heart disease. On examination, a harsh, holosystolic murmur grade 4 is auscultated at the left sternal border, with radiation to the back. Additionally, the second heart sound is widely split. Which of the following represents a major criterion of Nadas criteria for diagnosing ventricular septal defect (VSD) in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A harsh, holosystolic murmur grade 4 or greater at the left sternal border is a major criterion for diagnosing ventricular septal defect (VSD) according to Nadas criteria.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with congenital heart defects and upper limb abnormalities, including absent or hypoplastic thumbs. Cardiac evaluation reveals an atrial septal defect and a ventricular septal defect. Which of the following syndromes is most commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Holt-Oram syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Holt-Oram syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a combination of congenital heart defects (commonly ASD and VSD) and upper limb abnormalities, such as absent or hypoplastic thumbs.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9273
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9273

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with complex congenital heart disease presents with cyanosis, exercise intolerance, and clubbing of fingers. Cardiac evaluation reveals a single functional ventricle and severe pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for redirecting systemic venous blood directly to the pulmonary arteries, bypassing the right ventricle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fontan procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Fontan procedure is a definitive surgical intervention for patients with single-ventricle physiology, allowing systemic venous blood to be redirected directly to the pulmonary arteries, bypassing the right ventricle.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 2760
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 2760

questions.text: Match the following congenital heart defects with their corresponding anatomical descriptions: Tetralogy of Fallot Transposition of the great arteries Truncus arteriosus Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection Pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle, and the aorta arises from the right ventricle Single arterial trunk arising from both ventricles with a ventricular septal defect Ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy Pulmonary veins connect anomalously to the right side of the heart
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital heart defects are defined by specific anatomical abnormalities, and recognizing these features is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9455
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9455

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is noted to have cyanosis in the lower extremities while the upper extremities appear pink. Physical examination reveals a loud systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. Echocardiography confirms the presence of a right-sided aortic arch and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this presentation of differential cyanosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coarctation of the aorta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Differential cyanosis (cyanosis in the lower extremities but not in the upper extremities) is a hallmark of conditions involving a patent ductus arteriosus with right-to-left shunting, such as coarctation of the aorta .
  • ➤ coarctation of the aorta
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9274
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9274

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant presents with cyanosis and respiratory distress. Echocardiography reveals an abnormal venous connection where the pulmonary veins drain into the portal vein or the hepatic vein. Physical examination shows a single S2 heart sound and a prominent right ventricular impulse. Which of the following congenital heart defects is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?

options.label: C
options.text: Infra cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection

questions.correct_answer: C. Infra cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Infra cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infra cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) involves the pulmonary veins draining into the portal vein, hepatic vein, or inferior vena cava, causing cyanosis, respiratory distress, and increased right ventricular workload. It is confirmed by echocardiography.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9508
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 9508

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is evaluated for short stature and joint hypermobility. Radiographs reveal multiple fractures of varying ages. Which type of dwarfism is most likely associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Osteogenesis imperfecta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder characterized by recurrent fractures, short stature, joint hypermobility, blue sclera, and hearing loss. It is managed with bisphosphonates like alendronate or pamidronate to strengthen bones and reduce fracture risk.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 14,415
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 14,415

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents with breast development. She and her parents are concerned about early puberty. What is the most likely initial clinical sign of puberty in girls at her age?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Breast development.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thelarche (breast development) is the initial clinical sign of puberty in girls, while menarche (first menstrual period) is the final event in the sequence.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 11368
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 11368

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with concerns about delayed dentition. His parents report no teeth eruption yet. What is the most likely cause of delayed dentition in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Idiopathic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of delayed dentition in children is idiopathic , occurring in otherwise healthy individuals without systemic or genetic abnormalities.
  • ➤ idiopathic
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 7593
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 7593

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is not yet able to sit independently. What developmental milestone is most likely delayed in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gross motor skills.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sitting independently is a gross motor milestone , and a delay in this ability by 9 months indicates a potential delay in gross motor development.
  • ➤ gross motor milestone
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1105
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1105

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby had a toy train, whenever we hide the toy train he does not search for it. Today the baby is 9 months old, if his toy train is hidden, he searches for it. What do you call this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Object permanence is the cognitive milestone where an infant understands that objects continue to exist even when out of sight. It typically develops around 9 months of age and is crucial for tasks like searching for hidden objects.
  • ➤ Object permanence
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1134
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1134

questions.text: Match the developmental milestone with the appropriate age: Social Smile Immature Pincer Grasp Monosyllables Walks with one hand held 2 months 6 months 12-13 months 9 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-1, B-4, C-2, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Key milestones include social smile at 2 months, monosyllables at 6 months, immature pincer grasp at 9 months, and walking with support at 12-13 months .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with stunted growth, delayed development, and a protuberant abdomen. On examination, the child exhibits sparse, brittle hair, and a potbelly appearance. Laboratory investigations reveal low serum albumin and protein levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is characterized by protein deficiency leading to stunted growth, delayed development, protuberant abdomen, sparse brittle hair, and low serum albumin levels.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1842
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1842

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. In addition to growth assessment, which of the following age-independent indices is most useful in evaluating chronic malnutrition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MUAC is the most useful age-independent index for evaluating malnutrition in children aged six months to five years. A MUAC of less than 11.5 cm indicates severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1843
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1843

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a complaint of recurrent abdominal pain and discomfort. The caregiver reports noticing "sticky tape-like strands" in the child's stool. Stool examination reveals the presence of white, thread-like structures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis) infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis) infection is indicated by recurrent abdominal pain, nocturnal perianal itching, and "sticky tape-like strands" or thread-like worms visible in stool. It is treated with albendazole (200 mg for children <2 years, 400 mg for children ≥2 years).
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1844
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1844

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant presents with a history of poor weight gain, irritability, and persistent diarrhea. On examination, the child appears thin with visible ribcage and muscle wasting. Stool analysis reveals fat globules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Celiac disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease in infants presents with chronic diarrhea, poor weight gain, muscle wasting, and steatorrhea. Diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion and confirmation with serologic testing and intestinal biopsy .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8386
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 8386

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is admitted to the pediatric ward. During the initial assessment, the healthcare provider suspects hypoglycemia. What is the critical plasma glucose level that defines hypoglycemia in children with SAM?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) <54 mg/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypoglycemia in children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined as a plasma glucose level of <54 mg/dL and requires immediate treatment to prevent life-threatening complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1845
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1845

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit. The healthcare team notes decreased body temperature during the initial assessment. What is the critical core axillary temperature cutoff that defines hypothermia in children with SAM?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) <35.0°C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), hypothermia is defined as an axillary temperature of <35.0°C, which requires immediate and careful management to prevent complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1842
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1842

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) presents with irritability, muscle wasting, and a weight below the 5th percentile for age. Laboratory investigations reveal hypoalbuminemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Marasmus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition caused by calorie and protein deficiency, characterized by muscle wasting, severe weight loss, and absence of edema.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1843
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1843

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is being managed for severe acute malnutrition (SAM). Which of the following conditions should be promptly recognized and managed in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Refeeding syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refeeding syndrome is a critical complication of SAM management characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia. It requires gradual reintroduction of nutrition and close monitoring of electrolytes to prevent life-threatening complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1847
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1847

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for travel to a region with a high risk of diarrhea cases. What is the primary strain included in the Dukoral vaccine, and how does it confer protection?

options.label: A
options.text: Vibrio cholerae O1; Inducing intestinal immunity

options.label: B
options.text: Vibrio cholerae O139; Blocking bacterial colonization

questions.correct_answer: A. Vibrio cholerae O1; Inducing intestinal immunity
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vibrio cholerae O1; Inducing intestinal immunity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Dukoral vaccine targets Vibrio cholerae O1 and induces intestinal immunity, providing protection against cholera by preventing bacterial colonization and neutralizing cholera toxin.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 6084

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with beta-thalassemia intermedia experiences symptomatic anemia and splenomegaly. The healthcare provider contemplates hydroxyurea therapy to alleviate the symptoms. What is the primary therapeutic effect of hydroxyurea in beta-thalassemia intermedia, and how does it contribute to improving clinical outcomes?

options.label: A
options.text: Increases red blood cell lifespan; Decreasing iron overload

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulates erythropoietin production; Enhancing oxygen-carrying capacity

options.label: C
options.text: Suppresses ineffective erythropoiesis; Reducing transfusion dependence

options.label: D
options.text: Induces fetal hemoglobin (HbF) synthesis; Enhancing iron utilization

questions.correct_answer: D. Induces fetal hemoglobin (HbF) synthesis; Enhancing iron utilization
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Induces fetal hemoglobin (HbF) synthesis; Enhancing iron utilization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydroxyurea improves clinical outcomes in beta-thalassemia intermedia by inducing fetal hemoglobin (HbF) synthesis, which reduces anemia, decreases ineffective erythropoiesis, and improves oxygen-carrying capacity.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with hemophilia A presents with an acute joint bleed. The healthcare provider considers desmopressin (DDAVP) intranasal administration as part of the treatment plan. What is the primary mechanism of action of intranasal desmopressin in managing bleeding episodes in hemophilia, and what factor level is typically increased following its use?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulates von Willebrand factor release; Facilitating platelet adhesion

options.label: C
options.text: Raises factor VIII levels; Improving clotting capability

options.label: D
options.text: Elevates factor IX levels; Enhancing fibrinolysis

questions.correct_answer: C. Raises factor VIII levels; Improving clotting capability
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Raises factor VIII levels; Improving clotting capability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hemophilia A, intranasal desmopressin raises factor VIII levels, improving clotting capability and providing effective management for mild to moderate bleeding episodes.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 10,172

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with insidious onset of behavioral changes, cognitive decline, and myoclonic jerks. His medical history reveals a measles infection at 15 months of age. Physical examination shows evidence of motor and cognitive deterioration. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a fatal neurological disorder caused by persistent measles virus infection, presenting years after measles infection with cognitive decline, myoclonic jerks, and progressive neurological deterioration.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 6739

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with hearing loss, cataracts, and a patent ductus arteriosus. The mother reports a rash during the first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the infant's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) presents with a triad of sensorineural hearing loss, cataracts, and congenital heart defects (PDA). Maternal rubella infection in the first trimester is a key risk factor.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4293
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4293

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of starting steroids in tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steroids are indicated in tuberculosis for managing specific complications such as tubercular meningitis, TB uveitis, pericarditis, Addison’s disease, and severe miliary TB with alveolar-capillary block.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 6292
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 6292

questions.text: A 12-month-old child is scheduled to receive the first dose of the MMR vaccine. The child's mother is concerned about potential adverse effects and asks about the risk of febrile seizures following vaccination. What is the most appropriate response regarding the association between the MMR vaccine and febrile seizures?

options.label: A
options.text: Febrile seizures are a common side effect and occur in a significant proportion of vaccinated children.

options.label: B
options.text: There is no association between the MMR vaccine and an increased risk of febrile seizures.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of febrile seizures is higher after the MMR vaccine compared to other routine childhood vaccinations.

options.label: D
options.text: Febrile seizures occur only after the second dose of the MMR vaccine.

questions.correct_answer: B. There is no association between the MMR vaccine and an increased risk of febrile seizures.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) There is no association between the MMR vaccine and an increased risk of febrile seizures.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ There is no significant association between the MMR vaccine and an increased risk of febrile seizures. The vaccine is safe and critical for preventing measles, mumps, and rubella.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 12,056

questions.text: A nurse in a remote clinic receives a shipment of vaccines and notices that the storage unit consistently maintains a temperature of 10 degrees Celsius. Which of the following actions is most appropriate to address this situation and ensure the vaccine's efficacy?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue using the vaccines, as the temperature is within a reasonable range.

options.label: B
options.text: Adjust the thermostat to lower the storage temperature to the recommended range.

options.label: C
options.text: Report the temperature deviation to the supervisor and refrain from using the vaccines until the issue is resolved.

options.label: D
options.text: Warm the vaccines to room temperature before administration to compensate for the cooler storage.

questions.correct_answer: C. Report the temperature deviation to the supervisor and refrain from using the vaccines until the issue is resolved.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Report the temperature deviation to the supervisor and refrain from using the vaccines until the issue is resolved.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vaccines must be stored at 2–8 degrees Celsius. If a temperature deviation occurs, the appropriate action is to report the issue and refrain from using the vaccines until their efficacy can be verified.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 5524
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 5524

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is bitten by a pet dog with an unknown rabies vaccination status. The wound is bleeding, and the child's parents inquire about the need for rabies prophylaxis. What is the most appropriate recommendation in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer rabies vaccine and rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: Delay rabies prophylaxis and monitor the dog for signs of rabies.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer RIG only, as the dog is a pet and the wound is minor.

options.label: D
options.text: Rabies vaccination is not necessary for bites from pet dogs.

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer rabies vaccine and rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) immediately.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administer rabies vaccine and rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) immediately.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For Category 3 exposures, such as bleeding wounds from a dog with unknown rabies vaccination status, administer both rabies vaccine and rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) immediately.
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 7140
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 7140

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a severe dog bite, and rabies post-exposure prophylaxis is initiated. What is the most appropriate dose and route of administration for equine rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 40 IU/kg, intramuscular.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommended dose for equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG) is 40 IU/kg, administered intramuscularly, with as much of the dose as possible infiltrated around the wound site.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 7141

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician due to developmental delays and facial abnormalities. Physical examination reveals a smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, and a small head circumference. The child demonstrates poor coordination and exhibits behavioral problems. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is characterized by facial abnormalities (smooth philtrum, thin upper lip), growth retardation, and central nervous system deficits, all resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 4192

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the neonatal unit with multiple congenital anomalies including clenched fists, overlapping fingers, and a prominent occiput. Further evaluation reveals a low-set malformed ear and a small jaw and foot deformity. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most likely responsible for these clinical features?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is characterized by clenched fists with overlapping fingers, prominent occiput, low-set malformed ears, micrognathia, and rocker-bottom feet. It is caused by an extra chromosome 18.

  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 3024

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with persistent jaundice, characteristic facial features including a prominent forehead and deep-set eyes, and a murmur on cardiac examination. Further investigations reveal peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis and absent intrahepatic bile ducts. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician due to developmental delays, ataxic gait, and a happy demeanor with frequent episodes of inappropriate laughter. Physical examination reveals microcephaly, a protruding tongue, and a wide-based gait. Genetic testing confirms the absence of the maternal copy of chromosome 15.   • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st edition page number 1697

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the clinic for a developmental assessment. questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic with hearing loss and a goiter. questions.text: A neonate is born with a cleft palate, micrognathia, and glossoptosis, leading to airway obstruction and difficulty in feeding. questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with obesity, hypotonia, and excessive eating behavior. questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with intellectual disability, broad thumbs, and a characteristic facial appearance including down-slanting palpebral fissures and a beaked nose. questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of diarrhea. Physical examination reveals a scaly rash on sun-exposed areas, glossitis, and dementia like symptoms. questions.text: A 5-year-old child from a low-income community presents with dry, inflamed eyes and white foamy patches on the bulbar conjunctiva. questions.text: A 3-year-old child from a low-income community presents with profound muscle weakness, lower limb edema, and irritability. questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with seizures and irritability. Physical examination reveals a scaly, erythematous rash around the mouth and on the cheeks. questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency department with bleeding from the umbilical stump and ecchymoses on the skin. questions.text: Identification of “4Ds” is a key element of which national health programme?

options.text: IMNCI: Integrated management of neonatal & childhood illnesses

questions.correct_answer: C. RBSK: Rashtriya bal swathya karyakram

Ans. C) RBSK: Rashtriya bal swathya karyakram

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine are stored under the top rack compartment of the domestic refrigerator?

questions.text: Autistic spectrum disorder is characterised by which of the following? Tangential speech Inattentive Impulsive Hyperactive

questions.text: What is the anti dote to reverse the muscarinic effects of organophosphorous poisoning?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atropine is the antidote for reversing the muscarinic effects (e.g., salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea) of organophosphorous poisoning.

questions.text: A child develops stranger anxiety’ at:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stranger anxiety begins to develop at 6-7 months and is a normal part of infant development.

questions.text: After sustaining a head injury, an 18-month-old child displays eye opening only to pain, moans on painful stimuli and withdraws to painful stimuli. What is the modified Glasgow coma scale score in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Modified Glasgow Coma Scale score for this child is 8, indicating a moderate level of impaired consciousness.

questions.text: A child speaks bisyllables like Ma-Ma and Ba-Ba. He is able to sit without support and looks at the source of sound diagonally. What is the age of the child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 10 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 10 months, a child can speak bisyllables like "Ma-Ma," sit without support, and turn diagonally toward the source of a sound.

questions.text: A newborn delivered at 32 weeks gestation is started on spoon feeds after birth. On feeding with spoon, the baby demonstrates some spilling and coughing. What is the next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Orogastric or nasogastric tube feeding
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Orogastric or nasogastric tube feeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For preterm infants (32–34 weeks gestation) who exhibit feeding difficulties such as spilling and coughing, orogastric or nasogastric tube feeding is the next step in management.

questions.text: An infant was born at 30 weeks of gestation and weighs 1.2kg at birth. Which of the following is the recommended initial feeding method?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Orogastric feeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For preterm infants born at 28–32 weeks of gestation and weighing less than 1.5kg, orogastric feeding is the recommended initial method of feeding.

questions.text: Sickle cell syndromes are caused by a mutation in the b- globes gene. Which one of the following correctly describes the changes?

options.label: A
options.text: Sixth amino acid-glutamic acid is replaced by valine.

options.label: B
options.text: Twenty-sixth amino acid-glutamic acid is replaced by lysine

options.label: C
options.text: Sixth amino acid-glutamic acid is replaced by lysine

options.label: D
options.text: Ninety eighth amino acid-valine is replaced by methionine.

questions.correct_answer: A. Sixth amino acid-glutamic acid is replaced by valine.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sixth amino acid-glutamic acid is replaced by valine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sickle cell disease is caused by a mutation in the β-globin gene, where glutamic acid is replaced by valine at the sixth position, leading to the production of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS).

questions.text: 10 yr old boy with fatigue & abdominal pain after playing football. On detailed history there was also painful swelling of digits in the past. USG: small spleen; most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sickle cell anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sickle cell anemia presents with dactylitis, splenic atrophy, fatigue, and pain crises due to abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS), leading to hemolysis and vascular occlusion.

questions.text: Consider the following statements with respect to developmental milestones at 9 months of age: At this age, child develops immature pincer grasp. At this age, child can say bisyllables (mama, dada etc) At this age, child can wave bye-bye. Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At 9 months of age, a child typically develops an immature pincer grasp, can say bisyllables (mama, dada), and can wave bye-bye as part of their developmental milestones.

questions.text: What is the composition of ORS- Na, glucose, K, citrate, chloride?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 75, 75, 20, 10, 65

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO-recommended ORS composition is: Sodium 75 mmol/L, Glucose 75 mmol/L, Potassium 20 mmol/L, Citrate 10 mmol/L, and Chloride 65 mmol/L.

questions.text: Short stature is defined as height less than?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3rdpercentile / <-2 SD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Short stature is defined as a height below the 3rd percentile or less than -2 standard deviations (SD) on growth charts for age and sex.

questions.text: What is the formula to calculate the mid parental height for boys?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fathers ht + mothers ht / 2 +6.5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula to calculate mid-parental height for boys is:

questions.text: Which of the following condition flapping tremors is seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute hepatic encephalopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flapping tremors (asterixis) are most commonly seen in acute hepatic encephalopathy, resulting from elevated levels of neurotoxins such as ammonia due to liver dysfunction.

questions.text: Clinical features of an infant with Fetal growth restriction at birth include which of the following? Physical features give ’an old man look’. Baby is alert, reflexes are normal. There is presence of weight deficit. Thick fat accumulation around shoulder of baby. Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infants with fetal growth restriction typically have an "old man" appearance due to poor fat deposition, are alert with normal reflexes, and exhibit significant weight deficits at birth.

questions.text: What are the upper age limits by which a child should start walking alone, and be able to speak single words?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The upper age limit for a child to start walking independently is 15 months , and the upper age limit for speaking single words is also 15 months , even though many children achieve these milestones earlier.
  • ➤ 15 months
  • ➤ 15 months

questions.text: Which one of the following can be used for developmental screening for use in community to identify children (aged 0-6 years) with developmental delay?

options.label: A
options.text: Revised Denver developmental screening test (Denver II)

options.label: B
options.text: Ages and stages Questionnaire (ASQ-3) for children 1 month – 5 and a half years

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trivandrum development screening chart

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Trivandrum Developmental Screening Chart is the most suitable tool for developmental screening in the community for children aged 0-6 years .
  • ➤ Trivandrum Developmental Screening Chart
  • ➤ 0-6 years

questions.text: According to the WHO clinical criteria, which of the following clinical signs are indicative of ‘severe pneumonia or very severe disease’ in children aged 2 months to 5 years? Convulsions Lower chest indrawing Inability to feed Stridor in a calm child Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe pneumonia or very severe disease in children aged 2 months to 5 years is characterized by fast breathing and danger signs such as convulsions, lower chest indrawing, inability to feed, or stridor in a calm child.

questions.text: A full-term baby born with birth weight of 2500 g comes for well- baby visit at two months of age. Which of the following nutritional supplements would you advise?

options.label: A
options.text: Vitamin D orally 200 IU/day up to 3 months of age

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamin D orally 400 IU/day up to 1 years of age

options.label: C
options.text: Iron orally 2 mg/kg/day up to 3 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: Iron orally 2 mg/kg/day up to 1 years of age

questions.correct_answer: B. Vitamin D orally 400 IU/day up to 1 years of age
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin D orally 400 IU/day up to 1 years of age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a full-term baby, Vitamin D supplementation of 400 IU/day is recommended from birth up to 1 year of age to prevent Vitamin D deficiency and rickets .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: For developmental assessment of a baby, grasp is best assessed by offering the child:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A red cube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For developmental assessment of a baby's grasp, offering a red cube is the most appropriate method as it evaluates motor skill progression effectively.

questions.text: True about salmon patch? It is a hemangioma Site: nape of the neck Common in children Needs surgical excision

options.label: C
options.text: A + B + C + D IS Correct

questions.correct_answer: B. A + B + C IS Correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Salmon patches are common vascular birthmarks in children, often located on the nape of the neck, and they do not require surgical treatment as they typically resolve spontaneously.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vit D deficiency in children? Craniotabes Bossing of the frontal & parietal bones Muscle hypotonia Shrinkage of epiphysis at the lower end of radius
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 + 2 + 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin D deficiency in children leads to features like craniotabes, bossing of the skull bones, and muscle hypotonia. It does not cause shrinkage of the epiphysis but rather widening due to impaired mineralization.

questions.text: I am a 28-day old neonate came with complaints of failure to thrive, on further examination I was found to have a finding shown in the image. Please tell my nearest diagnosis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Menkes disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Menkes disease is characterized by failure to thrive, kinky hair, and copper metabolism defects due to ATP7A mutations. Early diagnosis is crucial for appropriate management.

questions.text: I am a 2-month-old baby with chubby rose cheeks. On further examination I was found to have optic + cognitive impairment. I am showing you one finding. Please tell my nearest diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Menkes disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Menkes disease is characterized by failure to thrive, optic and cognitive impairment, cutis laxa (loose skin), and copper metabolism defects due to ATP7A mutations.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with decrease school performance. On further examination slit lamp examination was done which shown the finding given below. What is the inheritance pattern shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Autosomal recessive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson disease, characterized by Kayser-Fleischer rings and copper metabolism defects, is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent irreversible organ damage.
